title: 114_s1121
content: The "Prevent All Soring Tactics Act of 2015" or the "PAST Act" increases enforcement under the Horse Protection Act. The Horse Protection Act is amended to define "action device" as any device encircling a horse's leg causing friction or striking the hoof, joint, or pastern, excluding certain protective boots. The Horse Protection Act is amended to define "participate" as engaging in activities related to horse shows, exhibitions, or sales, including transporting horses, giving instructions to exhibitors, and being present in restricted areas. Spectating is excluded from this definition. The Horse Protection Act is amended to include soring horses for purposes related to horse shows, exhibitions, or sales. The amendments aim to address unfair competition, deception of the public and horse buyers, and negative impacts on horse sales. The Inspector General of the Department of Agriculture has determined the effectiveness of the program. The Horse Protection Act is amended to address soring in Tennessee Walking Horses, Racking Horses, and Spotted Saddle Horses despite regulations in place. Amendments include changing inspectors to licensed individuals for horse shows and exhibitions. The Horse Protection Act is amended to address soring in Tennessee Walking Horses, Racking Horses, and Spotted Saddle Horses by disqualifying sore horses from being shown or exhibited for specific periods determined by the Secretary. Inspectors at horse shows and exhibitions will now be licensed individuals. The Secretary will regulate the licensing, training, and oversight of individuals to detect and diagnose sore horses at events, with a preference for licensed or accredited persons. Licenses may be revoked for unsatisfactory performance. The Secretary will regulate the licensing, training, and oversight of individuals to detect and diagnose sore horses at events, with a preference for licensed or accredited veterinarians. Licensed persons can be hired to conduct inspections at horse shows, exhibitions, sales, or auctions as assigned by the Secretary. The Horse Protection Act is amended to require licensed individuals to issue citations for violations, report violations to the Secretary, and publish information on violations on a public website for horse show management to check compliance. The Horse Protection Act is amended to include new unlawful acts such as causing a horse to become sore for showing or selling purposes. Additionally, licensed individuals are now required to hire individuals to issue citations for violations and report them to the Secretary. The Horse Protection Act is amended to prohibit the use of certain devices on Tennessee Walking Horses, Racking Horses, and Spotted Saddle Horses at shows, exhibitions, sales, or auctions. This includes action devices and weighted shoes that may cause soreness. This includes action devices and weighted shoes that may cause soreness. Violations and penalties for knowingly violating these regulations are also addressed. The Horse Protection Act is amended to increase penalties for violations, including fines up to $5,000 and imprisonment for up to three years for each violation. The Horse Protection Act is amended to increase penalties for violations, including fines up to $5,000 and imprisonment for up to three years for failing to obey disqualification orders or pay licensed inspectors. Violators may face disqualification from horse shows, exhibitions, or auctions for a year, with potential permanent disqualification for repeat offenses. The Horse Protection Act is amended to increase penalties for violations, including fines up to $5,000 and imprisonment for up to three years. The Secretary of Agriculture will issue regulations within 180 days to implement the amendments, including requirements for the Horse Protection Act. The Horse Protection Act (15 U.S.C. 1823(c)), as amended, includes provisions for increased penalties for violations. If any part of the Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act and its amendments will not be affected.
